column1: Bulkin was born in Brooklyn, New York, the son of David Bulkin and Anne Clara Strauss, both immigrants.
After a brief stint in Springfield, Massachusetts, he returned to Brooklyn, where he attended P.S. 197, an elementary school.
Bulkin was graduated from John Marshall High School (Los Angeles, California) in 1946 at age 16.
He then attended the University of California, Los Angeles, where he received a Bachelor of Science degree in aeronautical engineering.
By 1957, he was working as a design engineer.
He then took a job with Hiller Helicopters in Palo Alto, California, which provided cover for the then-classified Corona program, the first U.S. photo-reconnaissance satellite.

column2: Bulkin's colleagues credited him with proposing the use of ping-pong balls to cool the interior of one satellite module.

column1: From then until 1972, he was the director of advanced project development for the electro-optical division of International Telephone and Telegraph in Fort Wayne, Indiana.
Early on, observers noted the design continuity between the systems modules for the Hexagon and the LST.
After Lockheed won that contract in October 1977, Bulkin initially managed the equipment section.

column2: Lockheed became responsible for the physical integration of all systems aboard the HST.

column1: Bulkin described the April 24, 1990 launch of the Hubble Space Telescope as "like watching your mother-in-law go over a cliff in your brand-new Cadillac."
Asked at the time of the launch what scientists hoped to see with the new instrument, he said simply, "God."
Bulkin retired as Lockheed's Director of Scientific Space Programs in 1992.
He is survived by his widow Margaret Reed Talbot Bulkin.
